projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: CANTUS, Songs and Fancies, To Three, Four, or Five Parts, Both apt for Voices and Viols. With a brief Introduction to Mu≈øick, As is taught by Thomas David≈øon, in the Mu≈øick-School of Aberdene. Second Edition, Corrected and Enlarged.
ABERDENE, Printed by JOHN FORBES, and are to be ≈øold at his ≈øhop, Anno Domini. M.DC.LXVI.

div.head:
Unto the Right Honorable GILBERT GRAY Lord Prove≈øt.
ROBERT FORBES Bailie ALEXANDER ALEXANDER Bailie IOHN BURNET Bailie THOMAS MITCHELL Bailie WALTER ROBERTSON Dean of Gild, ROBERT SKENE Trea≈øurer, And to the re≈øt of the Honorable Coun≈øel of the City of ABERDENE.
div.p:
A few years ago, that I might approve my ≈øelf no le≈øs an ob≈øervant Citizen, then a provident Parent, being invited by the de≈øires of ≈øome,
allured by the kindne≈øs of others, and encouraged by the expectation and good hopes of the u≈øefulne≈øs of the thing it ≈øelf to the Place; I did lay down my Fir≈øt-born as a fondling, at the feet of Your Honorable Bench; ≈øolemnly engaging, that as it received its being from BON-ACCORD, and its growth from Your Goodne≈øs, ≈øo it ≈øhould period its ≈øtature with Your Plea≈øure. This Promi≈øe hath pre≈ø≈øed me, that my Pre≈øs might always bear the Impre≈øs of Your Vertues; and expre≈øs (though in a ≈ømal type) my thankfulne≈øs, according to the laudable cu≈øtom of Votaries in all Ages, after a few years growth, to repre≈øent the ≈øame to Your Sanctuary, that it may be confirmed in Your favor. For that I may confe≈øs ingenuou≈øly when I looked deliberatly on this my fir≈øt Mephibo≈øheth, I offered the ≈øame as an object of pity, being ≈øo mank and maim in its chiefe≈øt parts, like a pittiful Embleme of Orpheus teared by the Thracian women, its vigor ≈øeemed to wither, its tender hands to dry up, and whole body to vani≈øh in a con≈øumption; had I not called a Tymous Coun≈øel of the mo≈øt Expert in this Place, who diligently turning over their old Records, and rifling the labors of their Ance≈øtors, unanimou≈øly and ≈øo chearfully did contribute all their pains, that now being fred of all the noxious humors that were preying on its vitals, its wants are made up, defects ≈øupplyed, its dryed hands received moi≈øture, and ≈øtrength diffu≈øed ≈øo thorow the whole limbs, that it dare ≈øhow it ≈øelf to the Publick on its own leggs, if Your Wi≈ødoms command; yea, run to the Schools to warble the Anthems of Your Liberality. Seeing it is natural to children to li≈øp out fir≈øt their Parents names, why ≈øhould it be ≈øingular? If it did ≈øo when on the Nur≈øe brea≈øts, why not in the flower and prime of its youth?
Though it be ≈øilent, it hath a voice, and could ≈øing its own pedegrie, and the fruitfulne≈øs of its Mother Science; yea, with Strabo, Pindarus, Plutarch, Ari≈øtotle, and all Antiquity demon≈øtrate, how much brutes, as well as men, are born ob≈øequious ≈øubjects to this Queen, who≈øe charming Melody was only able to enchant Barbaritie, civilize Savages, ≈øecure Societies, and ≈øo give matter to the ≈øignificant Apologues of Amphion, Linus, Orpheus, and the building of the Theban walls, were it not the fear of being tedious, it would not be afraid to a≈ø≈øert with Divine Plato, and his Followers; that the Heavenly Soul by which the Vnivers is animate, doth owe its Origen to this Lady; and narrate how much the great Solon, that Sun of Greece, be≈øtowed on his Nephew, for teaching him one Saphick Tune: and how much pains the wi≈øe Socrates, though full of years, did greedily be≈øtow upon the Lute; and how much that greate≈øt Captain, and Magi≈øtrat of Athens Themi≈øtocles, after he had accompli≈øhed him≈øelf in all Vertue, and mo≈øt of Arts, was da≈øhed with the ≈øharp Sarca≈øme of a fellow Magi≈øtrat: How can he keep men in Harmonie, and people in Concord, who hath not learned as yet to tune a Citeron? It were no difficultie to ≈øhow how much the Ancients u≈øed this Science, as a remedy and amulet again≈øt all Fa≈øcinations: as the Harp of David, to alley the fury of Saul; and the greate≈øt auxiliarie al≈øo in time of Battle, ≈øo that the famous Stratonicus did di≈øcern the courage of his Souldiers, by the mu≈øical and ≈øaliant motion of their Bodies; and therefore, bearing a Citeron in his En≈øigne, did adde this motto, Adver≈øus male canentes Cythera; as if none de≈øerved Victory and Triumph but Mu≈øicians.

And now, ≈øeeing it hath plea≈øed Providence in Your Wi≈ødoms Per≈øons, to ble≈øs the Bench of BON-ACCORD with ≈øuch an Harmonious Con≈øort, of as many Mu≈øitians as Magi≈øtrats, that all under Your Magi≈øtracie may de≈øcant on Your Labors, and Po≈øteritie ≈øing Your Prai≈øes to coming Ages: Admit this Poor Pre≈øent to Your Acceptance; its Breath and Being depends on Your Brow, being willing to receive its Sentence from the ≈øame, whether it ≈øhal be ≈ømothered in the Birth, or view the Publick under Your Patrocinie: However, that the be≈øt Ble≈ø≈øings and Out-bearing of the ALMIGHTY, may accompany Your Wi≈ødoms in all Your Honorable De≈øigns, Shal be the dayly Prayer of

closer.signed: YOUR HONORS Own Servant, Iohn Forbes.

div.head: An Expo≈øition of the Gam, and Cliefs.
div.p: FOR the under≈øtanding of this fore-going Scale, you mu≈øt begin at the lowe≈øt word, Gam-ut, and ≈øo go upwards to the end, ≈øtill a≈øcending.

Then ye mu≈øt get it perfectly without book, to ≈øay it forewards and backwards. Secondly, you mu≈øt learn to know the parts of it, and wherein every key ≈øtandeth; that is, whether in Rule, or in Space. Thirdly, how many Clie≈øs, and how many Notes every key containeth. And la≈øtly, the properties of the Gam.
Q. How many parts is in the Gam?
A. Two.
Q. Which „Äà‚óä„Äâ ?
A. Ba≈øs and Alt.
Q. Which is Ba≈øs, and which is Alt?
A. All from Gam-ut, to C-≈øol-fa-ut, is Ba≈øs; and all from C-≈øol-fa-ut, to E-la, is Alt.
Q. C-≈øol-fa-ut, whether is it Ba≈øs, or Alt?
A. It is neither Ba≈øs nor Alt, but betwixt the two.
Q. What call you a Clief, and what a Note?

A. A Clief is a character ≈øet on a Rule at the beginning of a ver≈øe, ≈øhowing the height and lowne≈øs of every Note ≈øtanding on the ≈øame Ver≈øe, or in ≈øpace (although u≈øe hath taken it for a general rule, never to let any Clief in the Space, except the ‚ô≠ Clief) and every Space, or Rule, not having a Clief ≈øet in it, hath one under≈øtood, being only omitted for not pe≈øtering the Ver≈øe, and ≈øaving of labor to the writer: but here it is taken for a letter beginning the name of every Key, and are they which you ≈øee on the Scale ≈øet at the beginning of every word.
Q. How many Cliefs hath every Key?
A. Every Key hath but one Clief, except ‚ô≠-fa- ‚Ä¢ -rul, which hath two Cliefs.
Q. How many Cliefs are there?

A. There be in all ≈øeven Cliefs, A, B, C, D, E, F, G, but in u≈øe in ≈øinging there be but four; that is to ≈øay, the F-fa-ut Clief, which is commonly in the Ba≈øs, or lowe≈øt part, being formed or made thus ùÑ¢
The C-≈øol-fa-ut Clief, which is common to every part, and is made thus ùÑ°.

The G-≈øol-re-ut Clief in Alt, which is commonly u≈øed in the Treble, or highe≈øt part, and is made thus G. And the B Clief which is common to every part, and is made thus ‚ô≠, or thus ‚ôØ. The one ‚ô≠ ≈øignifying the half Note, or flat ≈øinging, the other ‚ôØ the whole Note, or ≈øharp ≈øinging.

div.head: Of the MOODS.
div.p: Q. HOw many Moods in there?
A. Four.
Q. Which four?
A. Perfect the More, and Imperfect the More; Perfect the Le≈øs, and Imperfect the Le≈øs.

div.head: The fir≈øt Mood.
div.p: Q. Perfect the More, whereby know ye it?
A. By my Figure and my Number.
Q. How know ye it by your Figure?
A A round circle with a prick ùáá
Q How know ye it by your Number?
A. They go all by threes, except Crochets, Quavers, and Semi-quavers.
Q. How go they?
A By twoes.
Q. Number that Mood.

A. Three Minims to the Semi-brief, ≈øo is the Semi-brief three; three Semi-briefs to the Brief, ≈øo is the Brief nine; three Briefs to the Long, ≈øo is the Long ≈øeven and twenty; three Longs to the Large, ≈øo is the large four ≈øcore and one.

figure.head: The Example of the fir≈øt Mood. Perfect the More.

div.head: The ≈øecond Mood.
div.p: Q. Imperfect the More, whereby know ye it?
A. By my Figure and my Number.
Q How know ye it by your Figure?
A. Half a Circle with a prick, ùáä
Q. How know ye it by your Number?
A. They go all by twoes, except Minims.
Q. How go they?
A. By threes.
Q. Number that Mood.

A. Three Minims to the Semi-brief, ≈øo is the Semi-brief three: two Semi-briefs to the Brief, ≈øo is the Brief ≈øix: two Briefs to the Long, ≈øo is the Long twelve: two Longs to the Large, ≈øo is the Large four and twentie.

figure.head: The Example of the ≈øecond Mood. Imperfect the More.

div.head: The third Mood.
div.p: Q. Perfect the Le≈øs, whereby know ye it?
A. By my Figure and my Number.
Q How know ye it by your Figure?
A. A round Circle without a prick, ùáà
Q. How know ye it by your Number?
A. They go all by twoes, except Semi-briefs.
Q. How go they?
A. By threes.
Q. Number that Mood.

A. Two Minims to the Semi-brief, ≈øo is the Semi-brief two: three Semi-briefs to the Brief, ≈øo is the Brief ≈øix: two Briefs to the Long, ≈øo is the Long twelve: two Longs to the Large, ≈øo is the Large four and twenty.

figure.head: The Example of the third Mood. Perfect the Le≈øs.

div.head: The fourth Mood.
div.p: Q. Imperfect the Le≈øs, whereby know ye it?
A. By my Figure and my Number.
Q. How know ye it by your Figure?
A. A half Circle without a prickùáã
Q. How know ye it by your Number?
A. They go all bv twoes.
Q. Number that Mood.

A. Two Minims to the Semi-brief, ≈øo is the Semi-brief two: two Semi-briefs to the Brief, ≈øo is the Brief ≈øour: two Briefs to the Long, ≈øo is the Long eight: two Longs to the Large, ≈øo is the Large ≈øixteen.

figure.head: The Example of the fourth Mood. Imperfect the Le≈øs.

div.head: The DEGREES.
div.p: Q. HOw many Degrees goeth to every Mood?
A. Three
Q Which three?
A. Mood, Time, and Prolation.
Q. What is Mood?
A. It is a mea≈øuring of Longs by Larges, and Briefs by Longs, and is either greater or le≈ø≈øer.
Q. What is the greater Mood.
A. It is a mea≈øuring of Longs by Larges, and is either Perfect or Imperfect.
Q. What is the greater Mood Perfect?
A. Three Longs to the Large.
Q What is the greater Mood Imperfect?
A. Two Longs to the Large.
Q What is the le≈ø≈øer Mood?
A. It is a mea≈øuring of Briefs by Longs, and is either Perfect or Imperfect.
Q. What is the le≈ø≈øer Mood Perfect?
A. Three Briefs to the Long.
Q. What is the le≈ø≈øer Mood Imperfect?
A. Two Briefs to the Long.
Q. What is Time?
A. It is a mea≈øuring of Semi-briefs by Briefs, and is either perfect or imperfect.
Q. What is perfect Tyme?
A. Three Semi-briefs to the Brief.
Q. What is imperfect Tyme?
A. Two Semi-briefs to the Brief.
Q. What is Prolation?
A. It is a mea≈øuring of Minims by Semi-briefs, and is either perfect or imperfect.
Q. What is perfect Prolation?
A. Three Minims to the Semi-brief.
Q. What is imperfect Prolation?
A. Two Minims to the Semi-brief.
Q Perfect the More, ùáá how goeth it in Mood, Time, and Prolation?
A. Perfect great Mood, perfect le≈øs Mood, perfect Time, and perfect Prolation.
Q Imperfect the More, ùáä how goeth it in Mood, Time and Prolation?
A. Imperfect great Mood, imperfect le≈øs Mood, imperfect Time, and perfect Prolation.
Q. Perfect the le≈øs, ùáà how goeth it in Mood, Time and Prolation?
A. Imperfect great Mood, imperfect le≈øs Mood, perfect Time, and imperfect Prolation.
Q Imperfect the le≈øs, ùáã how goeth it in Mood, Time and Prolation?
A. Imperfect great Mood, imperfect le≈øs Mood, imperfect Time, and imperfect Prolation.

div.head: The CONCORDS.
div.p: Q. WHat is a Concord?
A. It is a mixt ≈øound compact of diver≈øe voices, entring with delight in the ear, and is either perfect, or imperfect.
Q. What is a perfect Concord?
A. It is that which may ≈øtand by it ≈øelf, and of it ≈øelf maketh a perfect harmony, without the mixture of any other.
Q. VVhat is an imperfect Concord?
A. It is that which maketh not a full ≈øound, and needeth the following of a perfect Concord, to make it ≈øtand in the harmony.
Q. How many Concords is there?
A. Nine.
Q. VVhich nine?
A. An Uni≈øone, a third, a fifth, a ≈øixth, an octo, a tenth, a twelfth, a thirteenth, and a fifteenth.
Q. How many of them are perfect, and how many imperfect?
A. Five perfect, and four imperfect.
Q. VVhich are the five perfect?
A. An unitone, a fifth, an octo, a twelfth, and a fifteenth.
Q. VVhich are the four imperfect?
A. A third, a ≈øixth, a tenth, and a thirteenth with their octoes.
Q. VVhat mean you by their octoes?
A. Becau≈øe their octoes are but the ≈øelf ≈øame kind. As for example, An octo is the kind of an uni≈øone, a tenth is the kind of a third, & a twelfth the kind of a fifth, &c.
Q. VVhat needs ≈øo many Concords ≈øeeing there are ≈øo few kinds?

A. Albeit their kinds be one, yet the ≈øounds are diver≈øe. As an octo hath another ≈øound then an uni≈øone, and a tenth hath another ≈øort of ≈øound then a third, and a twelfth hath another ≈øort of ≈øound then a fifth, &c. As likewi≈øe it giveth bounds to the compo≈øer, or ≈øetter of parts.

list.head: Notes, their Names, Number, and Proportions. Example.

div.p: A further Example of the Prick-Notes, wherein you ≈øee your Mea≈øure of the Time barred, according to the Semi-brief, both by prick Semi-briefs, Minims, and Crochets.
Q. VVhat is a Ligature?

A. It is a combination or knitting together of two or more Notes, altering by their ≈øituation and order, the value of the ≈øame, holding out if your fir≈øt Note lack a tail, the ≈øecond de≈øcending, it is a long.
A ≈øecond Example. If the fir≈øt Note have a tail on the left ≈øide hanging downward: the ≈øecond a≈øcending or de≈øcending, it is a Brief.
Of final Notes in Ligatures. Every final Note of a Ligature de≈øcending, being a ≈øquare Note, is a long.

div.head: THE FIRST SONG.
div.p:
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
IF care doth cau≈øe men cry, Why do I not complain? If every
„Äà‚ô´„Äâ
wight bewails his woe, Why do I not the ≈øame?

lg.l: Since that among≈øt them all,
I dare well ≈øay is none
So far from joy, ≈øo full of woe,
Nor hath more cau≈øe to mourn.
For all things living hath
Sometime a quyet re≈øt;
The drawing Ox, the bearing A≈ø≈øe,
And every other bea≈øt.
